channel.title: [Gaming Rigs]
channel.description:
So for Christmas and my birthday, both coming up very soon, I'm going to ask for some parts to build a gaming PC. (Also, I have LOTS of cash saved up but I'm not willing to spend it if I don't have to.) So far, I've picked out several parts, and I wanted to know what you guys would think, also I want to know if you guys have your own setups. I've never built one before but I hear it's pretty basic, watching some videos, read some guides, and my best friends dad (self-proclaimed genius) works on these things for a living/has his own business. So hit me people.
Motherboard: ASUS M5A99X EVO AM3+ AMD 990X SATA 6Gb/s USB 3.0 ATX AMD Motherboard with UEFI BIOS Seller: Newegg.com Price: $129.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131754
CPU: AMD FX-4170 Zambezi 4.2GHz (4.3GHz Turbo) Socket AM3+ 125W Quad-Core Desktop Processor FD4170FRGUBOX Seller: Newegg.com Price: $119.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819106009
Memory: ADATA Premier Series 16GB (8 x 2GB) 240-Pin DDR3 SDRAM DDR3 1600 (PC3 12800) Desktop Memory Model AD3U1600W8G11-2 Seller: Newegg.com Price: $62.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820211716
Video Card: ASUS GeForce GTX 550 Ti ENGTX550 TI DC/DI/1G Video Card - 1GB, GDDR5, PCI-Express 2.0(x16), 1x HDMI, 1x Dual-link DVI-I, 1x VGA, DirectX 11, Dual-Slot, SLI Ready Seller: Tigerdirect.com Price: $134.99 Link: http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/SearchTools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=86839&CatId=3669
Hard Drive: Seagate ST310005N1A1AS-RK 1TB 7200 RPM 32MB Cache SATA 6.0Gb/s 3.5" Internal Hard Drive Seller: Newegg.com Price: $89.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822148321
PC Case: NZXT Apollo Black SECC Steel Chassis ATX Mid Tower Computer Case Seller: Newegg.com Price: $69.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811146025
Power Supply: NZXT HALE82-N NP-1BN-0750A-US 750W ATX 12V 2.3 and EPS 12V 2.92 SLI Ready CrossFire Ready 80 PLUS BRONZE Certified Active PFC Power Supply Seller: Newegg.com Price: $109.99 Link: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817116019 _________________________________________ Total: $717.93 + Tax & Shipping

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @Turmoilz1337x Turmoilz1337x
item.description:
@Turmoilz1337x wrote:

I’m looking to play runescape/wow/mostly guild wars 2/black ops 2.

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

if you spend more on a motherboard than a cpu you’re doing something wrong

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Instead of the FX processor, I would honestly just get an i5 and a gtx 670(At least 570) instead of the 550. I had a 550 ti and sent it back because it was shit. With the 550ti after 30 minutes of Skyrim, the fps would drop by a constant 10 or 12. It’s a bit more expensive to get the gtx 570 and i5 but it’s completely worth it. I have an AMD Phenom II X4 3.4Ghz Black series and a Gtx 560ti and I’m okay with it but I want more.

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

For the RAM, try getting 8 - 16GB with good frequency (1866+ MHz is good for gaming) and low latency. If you get higher frequency than 1600MHz, take a look if it is compatible with motherboard. Good website to make a build and make sure everything is compatible: www.pcpartpicker.com

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

It depends what games you want to be playing and the graphics you want to play at. Imo, 550 ti and a quad core is quite weak for top end games and won’t perform very well.

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Wow that ram is confusing. 8x2GB would make you assume 8 sticks of 2gb each. I would definitely get some better memory though, what you have in the OP is kinda slow

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

Yes that RAM is compatible.

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @Turmoilz1337x Turmoilz1337x
item.description:
@Turmoilz1337x wrote:

Thanks for the input, ill look into the RAM but I’ve done my research on this processor and really like it. TBH AMD is better for gaming. Also, I can say that from experience besides fact, I’m currently running an i7 and I’ve had AMD’s in the past. Though they weren’t high class, I found them on par with my current computer.

Other: Is that RAM compatible with my current mobo?

Read full topic

item.title: [Gaming Rigs]
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

Things that I would get if you wish to expand your budget: better memory (this one sucks, to be honest, here’s a good one: http://www.newegg.ca/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820220693), SSD and getting an Intel CPU instead of AMD. (Note that by changing the CPU, you would have to change the motherboard as well for it to be compatible).

Read full topic
